;;M;;任何运动;都可以声称是世界上最好的消遣。但当谈到产生伟大的文学作品时，棒球是独一无二的。美国图书馆把书架上的书架专门用于展示这项需要大脑、节奏缓慢的运动。他们收藏的书籍范围广泛，从最早的球员回忆录，如克里斯蒂·马修森 1912 年的《Pitching in a Pinch》，到著名小说家报道真实比赛的作品（约翰·厄普代克的文章《Hub Fans Bid Kid Adieu》）或重新想象比赛的作品（Don德里罗 1997 年的小说《黑夜传说》）。棒球也一直是社会变革的先兆。它的种族融合预示着民权运动。自由球员数百万美元薪水的上涨预示着 20 世纪 80 年代“贪婪是好事”的经济。这六本关于棒球的书不仅提供了对这项运动的愉快沉浸，而且还阐明了社会的一些更广泛的方面——美国并不是唯一一个为之着迷的社会。

;;

;;“84 年五十九”。; 作者：Edward Achorn。 ;哈珀柯林斯出版社； 400 页； 15.99 美元和 14.99 英镑;

;

;棒球历史爱好者可以滔滔不绝地讲述数百名前明星的成就和统计数据。但他们中只有一小部分人听说过这位在这项运动历史上创造了最伟大赛季的球员：查尔斯·“老霍斯”·拉德伯恩 (Charles “Old Hoss” Radbourn)，他是 1884 年排名第一的普罗维登斯格雷队 (Providence Grays) 的王牌投手。拉德伯恩在球队的比赛中首发并完成了 73 场比赛。 114场比赛。官方记分员将灰军 84 场胜利中的 59 场归功于他（他在 2019 年死后获得了第 60 场胜利）。可以肯定的是，当时的这项运动正处于青春期：拉德伯恩低手投球，他身后的外野手没有手套，全垒打很少见，有时是由于外野手因害怕观众的马下而拒绝取回球等奇怪现象造成的。被踢。但是，爱德华·阿霍恩 (Edward Achorn) 对拉德伯恩神奇的一年进行了生动且深入研究的描述，其最大的乐趣在于它表明，尽管镀金时代的美国似乎遥不可及，但棒球的情节和乐趣在今天基本上保持不变。

;

;;八人出局。; 作者：Eliot Asinof。; Henry Holt & 1py3sef e1v7vv2r0">;;八人出局。公司； 336页； 19.99 美元。石出版社； £18.95;

;

;美国的爵士乐时代始于黑袜队丑闻，其中芝加哥白袜队的球员与1919 年世界职业棒球大赛输给了辛辛那提红人队。艾略特·阿西诺夫 (Eliot Asinof) 在 1963 年描述的假球阴谋和随后的审判后来被拍成一部由约翰·库萨克 (John Cusack) 主演的电影，这并不是一部学术历史。它包括虚构的人物、从未发生过的事件以及虚构的对话和内心独白。这是一部根据真实故事改编的文学作品。它是有史以来最扣人心弦的棒球写作范例之一。

;

;;高薪奴隶。;作者：布拉德·斯奈德。 ;企鹅； 496 页； 17 美元。;

;

;自从棒球成为一项职业运动以来，其经济学一直围绕着寻求出售其服务的球员之间的紧张关系尽可能多的钱和团队老板寻求控制工资。对于20世纪的大多数球员来说，球员都受到抑制工资的“保留条款”的约束，该条款允许球队以上一年的工资无限期地续签合同，并在未经他们同意的情况下进行交易。在《高薪奴隶》中，布拉德·斯奈德讲述了科特·弗拉德（上图所示的击球手）的悲伤传奇，这位黑人外野手牺牲了自己的职业生涯来为球员赢得自由。 1969 年，当圣路易斯红雀队将弗拉德交易到费城费城人队时，弗拉德拒绝加入这座城市球迷种族主义声名狼藉的球队。他写信给这项运动的专员说，他不是“一块可以随意买卖的财产”。 Flood 将案件一路上诉至最高法院，最高法院 1972 年做出的有利于业主的裁决被广泛认为是最糟糕的裁决之一。四年后，棒球运动员工会设法通过仲裁推翻了保留条款，但弗拉德再也没有参加过比赛。

;

;;你必须拥有 Wa。罗伯特·怀廷著。 ;克诺夫； 416 页； $19;

;

;美国可能将棒球视为“全民消遣”，但在该国，棒球的受欢迎程度远远落后于橄榄球。相比之下，这项运动在东亚大部分地区和拉丁美洲部分地区占据主导地位。没有哪个地方比日本更成功，日本在五届世界棒球经典赛中赢得了三届冠军，并且是现效力于洛杉矶道奇队的大谷翔平的家乡。他是历史上唯一一位同时担任投手和击球手的球员。 （贝比·鲁斯在这两个角色中也表现出色，但不是同时出现。）对于只熟悉美国职业棒球大联盟的读者来说，罗伯特·怀廷通过日本和西方棒球文化差异的生动旅程是一个值得欢迎的纠正。棒球主要是击球手和投手之间一系列一对一的对抗，是最个性化的团队运动之一。但日本在培养明星球员和赢得国际冠军方面取得的成功是建立在通过严格训练实现的“和”理念上的，通常被翻译为“和谐”。搬到那里打球的美国球员更加个人主义。他们认为训练量由他们自己决定。他们对“wa”的理念及其对场内场外克己行为的要求感到困惑。怀廷先生以优雅和活力描述了文化冲突。

;

;;点球成金。迈克尔·刘易斯著。 WW诺顿； 336页； 17.95 美元和 12.99 英镑;

;

;即使在布拉德·皮特主演的电影版本于 2011 年上映之前，《点球成金》就有了强有力的支持成为有史以来最有影响力的棒球书籍。小市场奥克兰运动队如何利用统计分析来组建一支由被低估的球员组成的获胜球队的故事已经变得众所周知，以至于它的标题现在已经成为开箱即用的情报的代名词：有“政府的点球成金”、“律师的点球成金”、“农业科技创新的点球成金”，甚至是“荒地消防系统的点球成金”（谷歌搜索）。知识渊博的球迷可能会对田径队的成功到底有多少功劳，以及这支球队到底有多成功提出异议：在过去的 30 年里，它在季后赛中总共赢得了一场系列赛夺得棒球冠军。但由于迈克尔·刘易斯（Michael Lewis）对球队总经理比利·比恩（Billy Beane）的令人信服的心理描绘，这些狡辩很容易被忽视。比利·比恩对统计学家的信心源于他自己作为一名球员的失败，尽管他拥有球探渴望的身体素质。;

;;第四球。; 作者：Jim Bouton。 ;特纳出版公司； 508 页； 39.99 美元和 28.99 英镑;

;

;在每个明星球员的场外缺点都会成为小报素材的时代，很难想象那个时代，有关名人的不雅信息都被保密。但直到吉姆·布顿（上图所示的投手）在写下这本令人捧腹大笑、讲述自己 1969 年赛季的日记时，公众并不知道纽约洋基队受人尊敬的中外野手米基·曼特尔 (Mickey Mantle) 是个酗酒者，他的许多本垒打都是在宿醉状态下打出的，或者，球员们经常吸食安非他明（“绿党”），设计出各种方案来查找有吸引力的女性观众的裙子（“海狸射击”），并在公路旅行中猖獗地从事婚外情。 （当被问及成为一名棒球运动员最困难的部分时，迈克·赫根打趣道：“向你的妻子解释为什么她需要服用青霉素来治疗你的肾脏感染。”）美国职业棒球大联盟感到愤怒。其专员鲍伊·库恩（Bowie Kuhn）试图让布顿签署一份声明，称其内容纯属虚构，但没有成功，而布顿的揭露使他成为前队友中的贱民。每当皮特·罗斯（Pete Rose）这位后来被;禁止参加这项运动;的明星赌博，与布顿比赛时，他大喊“操你，莎士比亚！”

;;F;;Or millennia; people have selected dogs with useful or appealing traits and bred them.这就是为什么指针会指向，寻回犬会寻回，而且大多数宠物狗都很友好。尽管它们的下巴可能强大到足以咬碎骨头，但它们更有可能给你一个流口水的吻，而不是咬你。 However, some dogs have been bred for aggression, and it shows.

;

;In America in 2022 two children were killed and their mother was mauled while trying to save them from the family's pair of Extra Large (or “XL”) Pit Bull Terriers. Last September in England two ;XL美国恶霸犬;（两者关系密切）从附近房屋的窗户跳下攻击 52 岁的伊恩·普莱斯 (Ian Price)，并在他母亲的花园里杀死了他。 In January an XL Bully in Germany fatally mauled its owner and had to be shot as it rushed at police trying to help the man.

;
;

;

;In Britain the number of fatal attacks by dogs has quadrupled since the XL Bully was introduced to the country, from four in 2014 to 16 in the first nine months of 2023. Overall, XL Bullies were responsible for 44% of dog attacks in 2023, according to Bully Watch UK, a压力团体。 They killed other dogs, chewed children's faces and caused injuries so bad that arms needed amputating. In America Pit Bull attacks are growing more common and were responsible for nearly 70% of dog-attack deaths in 2019, according to DogsBite.org, a watchdog.

;

;Pit Bulls were bred to excel at dog-fighting, a sport that is banned in many countries but thrives in the shadows.规则简单而严厉。两只狗被放在一个坑里。只有一个出来。经过几代幸存的狗的繁殖，这些动物已经养成了一种攻击喉咙、毫无预警地发起攻击、忽视疼痛的倾向。 XL 恶霸犬是从比特斗牛犬中培育出来的，体型更大。因此，它们体型巨大（45-70公斤），具有攻击性，一旦开始攻击就很难阻止。 In “White Fang” Jack London called similar dogs “the clinging death”.

;

;Pit Bulls were banned in Britain in 1991. Similar bans or restrictions exist in Denmark, Germany, more than 1,000 American cities and some Canadian provinces.然而，在英国，XL Bullies 的进口商辩称，该禁令并未涵盖该新品种，尽管它本质上是一种更大的比特斗牛犬。该漏洞;在英格兰已被堵住; in December. Other countries should follow suit and outlaw the breed.

;

;There will be resistance, as there has been in Britain.一群被称为狗控制联盟的动物慈善机构和协会认为，法律应该关注“行为，而不是繁殖”。 Any kind of dog can be trained to be aggressive, they point out. They cite data from Britain's National Health Service showing that the number of dog bites has increased since the original Pit Bull ban. They call for laws that hold individual dogs and their irresponsible owners to account for bad behaviour.

;This is wrong-headed.确实，任何狗都可以接受战斗训练。但那些祖先经过选择性培育而擅长此道的人更有可能致命。 Aggregate data on dog bites are misleading, since they give equal weight to a nip from a chihuahua and a mauling from an XL Bully. This breed is so dangerous that it sometimes kills professional dog handlers.

;

;Sharing a home with a dog is one of life's greatest pleasures. But dog lovers have no right to endanger other people's lives by owning the most dangerous breeds. There are plenty of others to choose from. ;■;

;;V;;LADIMIR PUTIN; is a man who likes victories;最好是舞台管理的人。固定的选举胜利，然后举行令人振奋的音乐会。 A rousing Victory Day speech. Eight goals in an ice-hockey game.

;

;The dictator copes less well with unscheduled setbacks, preferring to disappear from the stage. In 2000 he fumbled his response to the Kursk submarine tragedy. He was absent for over a day following the failed storming of the Beslan school in 2004, in which 186 child hostages were killed. Last year, when ;Yevgeny Prigozhin; and his band of mercenaries made their way towards Moscow, Mr Putin was initially nowhere to be seen. So if he took a full 19 hours to conjure up a short ;TV; performance to speak about the massive intelligence failure at ;Crocus City Hall; in Moscow, he was falling into a familiar pattern.

;;
;

;;阅读我们最近对乌克兰战争的更多报道;;

;
;

;The address itself gave little away—and appeared to serve as a hedge. Mr Putin claimed, ludicrously, that Ukraine had opened a border “window” to the terrorists as they tried to escape Russia in their white Renault Symbol. (Eleven people that Russian authorities blame for the attack have been arrested.) But Mr Putin stopped short of directly attributing responsibility to Ukraine for the attack—and said nothing about the Islamic State group that said it had carried it out.

;

;Part of Mr Putin's reluctance to go all-in on blaming Ukraine might reflect a worry that the American government is sitting on intelligence that could undermine such a claim. Part might be embarrassment at his security agencies' failure to act on American warnings on March 7th of an imminent attack. Indeed, just three days before the assault Mr Putin had brushed off that intelligence as “blackmail”. Such a hubristic blunder would have consequences in a country where power can be held to account. Russia is not such a country.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The attack nevertheless represents a blow to the reputation of Mr Putin and the security services on which he depends. The manner of the assault, in which at least 137 people lost their lives, will not soon be forgotten. Some victims were killed within minutes when the gunmen opened fire from automatic rifles. But most succumbed to fire and smoke inhalation after the assailants set the auditorium ablaze. More than 200 people may have been in the hall when part of the roof collapsed. When emergency workers reached the smouldering ashes they found 28 bodies in a single toilet. Whole families had been hiding together, with mothers reportedly shielding their children.

;

;There are many questions over the inept security at the glitzy venue, which is in an entertainment park in Moscow's north-west suburbs. It is unclear why local police failed to respond quickly. A producer of a show held at Crocus City Hall ten days before the attack noted that 200 security guards were present that night. Some apparently unusual aspects of the attack—for supposed jihadists, the killers seemed keen to stay alive—have provoked conspiracy theories that parts of the Russian establishment may have been in on the act.

;

;The more convincing explanation is that an Islamist terrorist group capitalised on Russia's wartime distractions, ethnic tensions and economic difficulties. Russia offers obvious opportunities for jihadist recruitment from among poor migrants from the mostly Muslim former Soviet republics in Central Asia. Unofficial figures suggest that Russia has up to 8m migrants from Tajikistan alone.

;

;These migrants represent an important cog in the wartime economy, taking low-paid jobs that Russians do not want, like road-sweeping and minimum-wage construction. But ethnic tensions have been rising. Mr Putin spoke to them indirectly in his state-of-the-nation speech on February 29th, dialling down his previous nationalist rhetoric and emphasising Russia's “multi-ethnicity”.

;
;Islamic State-Khorasan Province;. Based mainly in Afghanistan but with followers across Central Asia, it carried out twin bombings in Iran in January that killed over 100 people. One of the sources of its grievances against Russia is the country's involvement in the war in Syria, where the Kremlin (along with Iran) has backed the Assad regime against Islamic State and other rebels. Islamic State is also suspected of carrying out an attack on the metro in St Petersburg in 2017 that killed 15 people.

;

;After previous crises Mr Putin responded to any questioning of his power by gripping it tighter. When he finally reappeared after the Beslan massacre, he declared “the weak get beaten” and cancelled direct local elections. The crackdowns on dissent and press freedom that followed were a harbinger of worse to come. More recently Mr Prigozhin's mutiny saw his plane ;blasted out of the sky; after he had supposedly reached a deal with his boss.

;

;The Kremlin will no doubt use the Moscow attack as a pretext to tighten the domestic screws further. Some of its most loyal lieutenants have called for the cancellation of Russia's moratorium on the death penalty for terrorism. That threat takes on extra significance in light of the Kremlin's recent habit of applying that label to opponents of the regime, including an elderly writer of crime fiction. Migrant communities are already feeling the pinch, with raids on mosques and hostels reported in major cities across Russia. But there is propaganda value in blaming Ukraine, and there are economic risks attached to threatening migrant workers. So the Kremlin is unlikely to deal with its security vulnerabilities systematically.

;

;Indeed, Mr Putin hinted that the main consequences of the terror attack will be felt in Ukraine. He may use it to justify attempts to mobilise more troops for his war there. Kremlin-linked media are helping shape the narrative. One published an “investigation” suggesting that the terrorists were recruited by the Ukrainian embassy in Tajikistan. Activists from antibot4navalny, a cyber-monitoring group, have recorded a notable uptick in the social-media activity of bots controlled by the ;FSB;, Russia's security agency. Most of the fake news blamed Ukraine, as well as America and Britain, for the Moscow attack.

;

;An intelligence source in Ukraine says he expects such efforts to be stepped up, using flimsy arguments to redirect blame. “Perhaps they will start blaming France, too,” he quips. “After all, the men escaped in a Renault.”;■;

;;“G;;eneral Hospital”; has the distinction of running longer than any soap opera in American television history. Yet the months-long budget melodrama in Washington, ;DC;, which mercifully concluded on March 23rd, at times felt destined to become almost as much of a fixture of American life as the medical serial that debuted in 1963.

;

;The 2024 fiscal year began nearly six months ago, but only now has Congress managed to pass a long-term budget deal to fully fund the federal government through the remainder of the fiscal year. ;Kevin McCarthy; was ousted as House speaker in October 2023 after preventing a lapse in government funding. ;Mike Johnson;, his successor, allowed three more “continuing resolutions” to avoid unnecessary government shutdowns, but the delays culminated in an agreement that differed little from what the White House and Congress had agreed to in principle nearly a year ago.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The $1.2trn package just passed covers about 75% of government spending. （其余部分已在本月早些时候签署成为法律的法案中获得授权。）最新立法于 3 月 22 日周五在共和党控制的众议院以 286 票对 134 票获得通过，而民主党领导的参议院在经过多次投票后批准了该法案。周六凌晨，最后一刻的讨价还价以 74 比 24 进行。 The bill, more popular with Democrats than Republicans, marginally reduces government spending but on its own won't significantly alter America's fiscal destiny.

;

;“It's good to see Congress put something in place to control spending levels for one year,” says Maya MacGuineas, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a bipartisan non-profit group.这并不意味着国会议员应该沾沾自喜。 “There's so much more to be done, and they are all the things that politicians are saying they won't do, including raising taxes, fixing Social Security and fixing Medicare.”

;

;Underperformance has never prevented legislators from claiming victory anyway.民主党和共和党都会很高兴为军人加薪 5.2%，甚至一些共和党人也会为向试图逃离塔利班统治的美国在阿富汗盟友发放 12,000 个新的特殊移民签证而欢呼雀跃。 The bill also includes policy prizes that fall under neater partisan categories.

;

;Mr Johnson won new money for Immigration and Customs Enforcement to expand immigration-detention capacity and pay for 22,000 border-patrol agents. Republicans also secured a one-year ban on funding for the ;UN; Relief and Works Agency, which provides aid to Palestinian refugees, along with a 6% reduction in broader spending on foreign programmes. All are real wins for a party increasingly supportive of Israel, sceptical of immigration and isolationist in its global outlook.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Democrats, however, blocked a host of other policies popular among Republicans, such as anti-abortion provisions. Members of Mr Biden's party are also touting $1bn for a climate-change programme at the Pentagon and another $1bn for child care and Head Start, an education programme for young children from poor families. This mixed outcome in any deal ought to be expected, given America's divided government, but Republican hardliners were not impressed.

;

;Chip Roy, a congressman from Texas, acknowledged after the bill was released that Republicans would not get everything they wanted when Democrats controlled the White House and Senate. He opposed the measure regardless. “Any Republican who votes for this bill OWNS the murders, the rapes and the assaults by the people that are being released into our country,” Mr Roy said, citing its insufficiently harsh immigration provisions. “A vote for this bill is a vote against America.”

;

;Mr McCarthy lost his job after years of enduring this sort of over-the-top rhetorical abuse, but his replacement has largely followed his lead. The final deal had been negotiated behind closed doors between Mr Biden's team and congressional leaders. Mr Johnson listened to the hardline Freedom Caucus, to which Mr Roy belongs, but ultimately ignored the group. To avoid a government shutdown, he even ignored a rule that previously required the House not vote on a bill until 72 hours after its text was released.

;

;As a relatively unknown congressman, Mr Johnson was one of the most conservative members of the lower chamber. He is still deeply conservative, but the price of power is recognising the need to compromise. The provisions in this bill will expire at the end of September, weeks before the presidential election. In all likelihood a short-term spending bill will be cobbled together to carry legislators through campaign season, to avoid a messy spending fight just as Americans get ready to vote.

;

;For now, Mr Johnson has said that he would turn his focus to providing aid for Israel, Taiwan and Ukraine. He previously declined to take up a Senate bill that paired military assistance with immigration reform, and some members of the House are working on a strategy to force a vote on the issue. If Mr Johnson supported assistance for Ukraine after cutting a deal with Democrats, could he meet the same fate as Mr McCarthy?
